ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Sensorineural hearing loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Bilateral mild sloping to moderately severe hearing loss with symmetrical configuration.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Inadequate hearing aid fitting
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Initial open-fit settings provided insufficient high-frequency gain due to feedback limitations, resulting in poor clarity and benefit.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Visual inspection of the ear canal and tympanic membrane.
Assess hearing sensitivity to confirm degree and configuration of loss.
Evaluate speech reception thresholds and word recognition abilities.
Verify hearing instruments are functioning according to manufacturer specifications.
Assess audibility of hearing aid output in the patient's ear relative to targets.
Determine maximum stable gain available before feedback occurs.
Assess potential occlusion effect with closed domes.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The patient has a bilateral mild sloping to moderately severe sensorineural hearing loss. Her hearing aids were functioning correctly electroacoustically but were poorly fitted; the open-dome coupling caused feedback limitations that prevented adequate high-frequency gain. Switching to closed domes and reprogramming to DSL v5.0 targets resolved the under-amplification and feedback issues without causing occlusion.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Mild sloping to moderately severe sensorineural hearing loss bilaterally; symmetrical configuration.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRTs consistent with pure-tone averages (R 40, L 35 dB HL); WRS showed slight difficulty (R 80%, L 84% at 65 dB HL).

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Normal tympanic membrane performance (Type A) bilaterally.

tests.name: Electroacoustic Analysis
tests.result_summary: Devices functioning appropriately compared to manufacturer ANSI specifications; no distortion or internal noise.

tests.name: Real Ear Measures (REM)
tests.result_summary: Pre-adjustment: Significant under-amplification relative to DSL v5.0 targets, particularly >2000 Hz. SII (Left): Soft 27, Avg 47, Loud 64.

tests.name: Feedback Analysis
tests.result_summary: Maximum stable gain was significantly lower than available gain due to open-vent condition, preventing adequate high-frequency amplification.

tests.name: Real Ear Measures (REM)
tests.result_summary: Post-adjustment (with closed domes): Improved high-frequency audibility matching DSL v5.0 targets; occlusion effect test showed no issues. SII (Left): Soft 45, Avg 71, Loud 79.

tests.name: Occlusion effect test
tests.result_summary: No significant occlusion effect measured objectively or reported subjectively.

proposed_items: Change hearing aid coupling from open domes to closed domes to increase maximum stable gain.
Reprogram hearing instruments to match DSL v5.0 targets.
Verify new settings using Real Ear Measures (REM) to ensure audibility.
Perform static feedback test to confirm feedback resolution.
Conduct occlusion effect test to ensure patient comfort with closed domes.
counseling_actions: Explain that the previous open-fit tips allowed sound to escape, causing feedback and preventing necessary high-pitch volume.
Counsel that switching to closed domes keeps sound in the ear, stops whistling, and allows for sharper speech clarity.
Confirm with the patient that the new settings do not cause their own voice to sound 'funny' (occlusion).

escalation.rationale_short: Patient requires routine audiological follow-up to monitor hearing aid performance; no medical referral indicated.

follow_up_plan.objective: Follow-up call to assess performance, clarity, and satisfaction with the new hearing instrument settings.

expected_outcome: Patient reported hearing significantly better with noticeable improvement in clarity, sound quality, and speech recognition in various environments.
Patient reported no concerns with own voice (occlusion) and no further concerns with device performance.
